DOC.HEAD: Economists Say Subsidies Not Answer to Defense-Linked Economy
With AM-Bush-Budget, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Cuts in U.S. military spending in response to a waning Soviet threat will create economic problems in defense-oriented regions, but a group of economists said Tuesday that federal subsidies aren't the answer. ``Major federal spending to support particular regions is counterproductive to the economy,'' Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, told Congress' Joint Economic Committee. ``Regional interests overwhelming the national interest is part of the problem, not part of the solution,'' he said. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is considering cuts in the armed forces and cancellation or lengthening weapons programs as part of an effort to reduce the defense budget. Last month, Cheney directed the services to come up with between $140 billion and $180 billion in cuts from the fiscal 1992 to 1994 military budgets. Straszheim and two other economists testifying before the committee, which is examining the economic adjustment after the Cold War, said cuts in military spending will affect defense contractors nationwide. However, they said financial assistance from Washington and a national job retraining program should not be options. Pressed by Rep. James Scheuer, D-N.Y., Straszheim said that although the approach was a ``cold, hard position of doing nothing,'' he would not suggest a wide-ranging program to help areas that might be financially strapped. ``A few years ago, Texas was devastated when oil prices went up and then down. ... That's life,'' Straszheim said. Scheuer, whose district includes parts of New York City and Long Island, wondered about Grumman Corp., the Long Island manufacturer of the Navy's F-14D Tomcat jet fighter. Cheney, in the fiscal 1990 defense budget, proposed canceling the program. Congress agreed to continue it for one more year but forced Grumman to sign an agreement that included a termination clause. ``Grumman sits over that Long Island economy like a 600-pound canary,'' Scheuer said. ``What do we do about the 10,000 employees at risk? What do we do about the Long Island economy? Do we have a retraining program?'' Other hard hit areas that rely heavily on defense business include San Antonio, San Diego and the tidewater region of Virginia. Charles L. Schultze, director of the economic studies program at the Brookings Institution, said the adjustment from cuts in defense would be no different from changes that occur every year across the nation in other businesses. ``This isn't a big deal,'' Schultze said.
